references: One of the key factors of             ACT            is that all of the contrastive pairs highlight differences between pragmatic actions (e.g. asking a question versus providing an answer). As indicated in the main results (Tables                     1                   ,                     2                   ,                     3                   ), we see that Naive DPO (i.e., when we sample preference pairings from LLMs without action specification) underperforms             ACT            . In Table                     5                   , we additionally examine the importance of action selection by randomly sampling             both the winning and losing action            when constructing the preference pair, and observe this underperforms normal             ACT            .

In Table                     5                   , we also consider whether it is sufficient to remove sampling altogether, i.e. using the normal DPO algorithm on the action-based preference dataset as constructed in Section                     3.2.1                   . While we do observe some improvements over SFT (e.g., from 69.0 to 74.8 in terms of Macro F1 and from 57.8 to 61.5 in terms of turn-level DROP F1), the overall improvements are much larger when using on-policy sampling as with full             ACT            . This may be due to the fact that the LLM-sampled negative responses are not guaranteed to lie within the language manifold of the tuned policy model, making the training example too ‚Äúeasy.‚Äù Similarly, distribution shift is the key motivating factor the proposed online variant of DPO in             [               42              ]            .

We propose             ACT            as an approach which is better-aligned with multi-turn conversations due to its trajectory-level simulation from the policy model. In Table                     5                   , we find that removing trajectory-level simulation (while including on-policy response sampling for the purpose of determining pragmatic-level actions) results in degraded performance in terms of post-clarification DROP F1. This indicates that the model is better able to reason about its own clarification questions when tuned with trajectory-level simulation. We do note that this condition does outperform both SFT and             ACT            without any sampling (particularly in terms of Macro F1).

In all of our experiments with             ACT            , we used Zephyr 7B-                              Œ≤                                   ùõΩ                                  \beta                           , a version of Mistral 7B which has already been aligned with DPO. In Table                     5                   we also examine the impact of directly tuning two base foundation models, Mistral 7B and Gemma 2B. Directly comparing the baseline SFT performance with Mistral 7B against Zephyr 7B (see Table                     1                   ), we can see there is already a noticeable gap in all metrics. After applying             ACT            , while Mistral 7B‚Äôs performance does improve, it does not achieve the same performance as Zephyr.

references: We start from Spider, a popular single-turn text-to-SQL dataset and benchmark. An overview of AmbigSQL is given in Table                  A6                . Due to the nature of the single-turn requests in Spider, each instance can be viewed as a conversation consisting of a single state                                   t                         1                                                 subscript                            ùë°                            1                                       t_{1}                       (see notation defined in Section                  3                ).                    is the correct SQL query which yields the information requested by the user.                                             g                            1                                  =                                   r                            1                                                                                       subscript                               ùëî                               1                                                 subscript                               ùëü                               1 id_table_3.caption: Table A7: Conversations in CoSQL with noisy ‚Äúclarification questions‚Äù (highlighted in red ). Example 1) is a remnant of crowdsourcing in which the system-side party makes mention of the task guideline. Example 2) demonstrates a system-side clarification question being asked prior to the user making any information requests. Example 3) The system-side clarification question makes reference to some prior database search result, but the execution feedback is not made accessible to the system during inference.
table: Assistant
SELECT Name FROM singer WHERE Singer_ID NOT IN ...
User
Thanks!
1
Assistant
You should ask at least 3 questions
2
Assistant
Did you want the full name of makers and the number?
3
Assistant
Do you mean the address of the customer with first name Luis?
references: There is growing interest in using LLM-based agents for coding tasks         [           46          ]        . Particularly, due to the complexity of such tasks, multi-turn interactions in which an agent is able to clarify assumptions and user intents should intuitively help with goal completion         [           64          ]        . Despite this, there are few existing resources for multi-turn code generation tasks. One example is CoSQL, a conversational text-to-SQL task which also includes linguistic ambiguities         [           65          ]        , but the proposed task does not include agent-style interaction in which a model must learn to ask clarifying questions. Upon our inspection of the dataset, there are also various inconsistencies related to the ‚Äúsystem-side‚Äù clarification questions given in the dataset‚Äôs conversational contexts, which we highlight in Table               A7             . As a result, we propose AmbigSQL, our own synthetically constructed resource for ambiguous conversational text-to-SQL.

id_table_4.caption: Table A8: In-context example given as part of a prompt for creating information requests in which the target population is ambiguous. The format of the black text represents how a ground-truth request would be used to form the prompt for a target example. The blue text represents the content that would be synthesized from an LLM. We omit the database schema from the paper.
table:
The target SQL query is the following: 
SELECT professional_id ,  last_name ,  cell_number FROM Professionals
WHERE state  =  ‚ÄôIndiana‚Äô UNION SELECT T1.professional_id ,  T1.last_name ,
T1.cell_number FROM Professionals AS T1 JOIN Treatments AS T2 ON
T1.professional_id  =  T2.professional_id
GROUP BY T1.professional_id HAVING count(*)  >  2
Here is a clear request that would correspond to this SQL query:
‚ÄúWhich professionals live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments? List his or her id, last name and cell phone.‚Äù
Here is the same request converted into an ambiguous format by underspecifying the target columns:
‚ÄúWhich ones live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments?‚Äù
Here is an appropriate clarifying question to recover the clear request from the ambiguous request:
‚ÄúAre you asking about the Professionals?‚Äù
references: We focus on three fundamental types of ambiguous information requests. Those in which the requested information is ambiguous (e.g., ‚ÄúShow details about singers ordered by age from the oldest to the youngest‚Äù), those in which the requested population is ambiguous (e.g., ‚ÄúWhich ones who live in the state of Indiana?‚Äù; see Table                  A8                ), and finally, those in which the requested presentation of results is ambiguous (e.g. ‚ÄúShow name, country, age for all singers ordered by age‚Äù; see Table                  A9                ).

We iterate through each of the examples in Spider, and use an LLM (Gemini Ultra 1.0) to synthesize a perturbed version of each unambiguous query, along with an appropriate clarifying question. For queries which require some manipulation of results presentation, we prompt an LLM to perturb the query such that the requested presentation style becomes ambiguous. Otherwise, we randomly select a perturbation strategy: either masking the requested information (Table                  A9                ) or masking the requested population (Table                  A8                ). For each of these three strategies, we use five in-context examples demonstrating the appropriate masking process. The exact in-context examples are given in the attached code. Each of these ambiguous queries are thus associated with conversations containing ‚Äúground truth‚Äù states at two timesteps,                                   t                         1                                                 subscript                            ùë°                            1                                       t_{1}                       and                                   t                         2                                                 subscript                            ùë°                            2                                       t_{2}                       .                                   p                         1                                                 subscript                            ùëù                            1                                       p_{1}                       contains an ambiguous user request,                                   r                         1                                                 subscript                            ùëü                            1                                       r_{1}                       is the synthesized clarification question, and accordingly,                                             a                            1                                  =                                   C                            ‚Äã                            L                            ‚Äã                            A                            ‚Äã                            R                            ‚Äã                            I                            ‚Äã                            F                            ‚Äã                            Y                                                                                       subscript                               ùëé                               1                                                                     ùê∂                               ùêø                               ùê¥                               ùëÖ                               ùêº                               ùêπ                               ùëå                                                 a_{1}=CLARIFY                       .                                   p                         2                                                 subscript                            ùëù                            2                                       p_{2}                       contains the disambiguated user request,                                   r                         2                                                 subscript                            ùëü                            2                                       r_{2}                       is the correct ground truth SQL query, and accordingly,                                             a                            2                                  =                                   A                            ‚Äã                            N                            ‚Äã                            S                            ‚Äã                            W                            ‚Äã                            E                            ‚Äã                            R                                                                                       subscript                               ùëé                               2                                                                     ùê¥                               ùëÅ                               ùëÜ                               ùëä                               ùê∏                               ùëÖ                                                 a_{2}=ANSWER                       .

We iterate through each of the examples in Spider, and use an LLM (Gemini Ultra 1.0) to synthesize a perturbed version of each unambiguous query, along with an appropriate clarifying question. id_table_6.caption: Table A11: Examples from the AmbigSQL test set using the ‚Äúconcert_singer‚Äù database. Black text: context provided to an LLM as a prompt. Blue text: ground-truth single-turn response. Purple text: target trajectory which should be achieved through simulation.
table: You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question.
[ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ]
[ [ [ Conversation ] ] ]
User: How many singers do we have?
Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM singer
[ [ [ Instruction ] ] ]

You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question.
[ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ]
[ [ [ Conversation ] ] ]
User: Tell me about the singers.
Assistant: What specifically would you like to know about the singers? For example, would you like to know how many there are, or see a list of their names?
User: How many singers do we have?
Assistant: SELECT count(*) FROM singer
references: Table                  A11                and Table                  A12                each contain a pair of examples from AmbigSQL‚Äôs test set. Each example contains the prompt which is provided to an LLM, the immediate ground truth response to the user request provided as part of the prompt, and the resulting ground truth trajectory (for examples which include clarifying questions). The examples in each table are paired ‚Äî the top example is directly taken from Spider and converted into a conversational format, and the bottom example is the result of introducing ambiguity into the first example.

id_table_7.caption: Table A12: Examples from the AmbigSQL test set using the ‚Äúflight_2‚Äù database. Black text: context provided to an LLM as a prompt. Blue text: ground-truth single-turn response. Purple text: target trajectory which should be achieved through simulation.
table: You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. You are an Assistant having a conversation with a User who would like to retrieve some information from a SQL database with the schema provided below. If you are confident in the User‚Äôs intent, you should provide the appropriate SQL query. Otherwise, you should ask the User a clarifying question.
[ [ [ Database Schema Omitted ] ] ]
[ [ [ Conversation ] ] ]

Assistant: Could you please specify which table you are referring to when you ask ‚ÄôHow many are there?‚Äô

references: Table                  A11                and Table                  A12                each contain a pair of examples from AmbigSQL‚Äôs test set. Each example contains the prompt which is provided to an LLM, the immediate ground truth response to the user request provided as part of the prompt, and the resulting ground truth trajectory (for examples which include clarifying questions). The examples in each table are paired ‚Äî the top example is directly taken from Spider and converted into a conversational format, and the bottom example is the result of introducing ambiguity into the first example.

id_table_8.caption: Table A13: ‚ÄúStandard‚Äù in-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for response generation in PACIFIC. The purple text is the overall system instruction. The blue text is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ]
User: How much does the company expect to make contributions to the defined plans during the next fiscal year?
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of defined plans are you asking about?‚Äô]
User: The defined benefit plans and the defined contribution plan respectively.
Assistant: [‚Äô$5.1 million‚Äô, ‚Äô$0.6 million‚Äô]
User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year?
Assistant: 0.6/5.1 = 11.76
User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate?
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of change are you asking about?‚Äô]
User: The pension.
Assistant: [‚Äô$(39,145)‚Äô, ‚Äô$49,361‚Äô]
User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease?
Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506
User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively?
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô]
User: The future salary growth.
Assistant: [‚Äô$7,572‚Äô, ‚Äô$(6,919)‚Äô]
User: What is the difference between them?
Assistant: 7,572 - (6,919) = 14491
references: We simply provide in-context examples that are structurally identical to the inputs used for model tuning. Our format is similar to the formats used in           [             24            ,             59            ]          and we provide an example in Table                  A13                .

id_table_9.caption: Table A14: ‚ÄúChain-of-Thought‚Äù in-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for response generation in PACIFIC. The purple text is the overall system instruction. The blue text is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ]
User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year?

User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate?

User: The pension.

Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question is not ambiguous. Assistant: [‚Äô$(39,145)‚Äô, ‚Äô$49,361‚Äô]
User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease?

Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step.
Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question is not ambiguous. Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506 User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively?

Instruction: If the user‚Äôs question is ambiguous, ask an appropriate clarifying question. Otherwise, directly answer the user‚Äôs question using the information from the passage context and the table. Let‚Äôs think step by step.
Reasoning: The user‚Äôs question was ambiguous.
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô]
references: We integrate the popular reasoning framework, chain-of-thought prompting           [             58            ]          into our aforementioned ‚ÄúStandard‚Äù conversational prompt format. Effectively, we ask an LLM to do end-to-end dialogue generation by having it first produce a reasoning chain which states whether the current context is ambiguous or not. We provide an example in Table                  A14                .

id_table_10.caption: Table A15: ‚ÄúProactive Mixed-Initiative‚Äù in-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for response generation in PACIFIC. The purple text is the overall system instruction. The blue text is what an LLM would have to produce at inference time.
table: [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ]
User: How much does the company expect to make contributions to the defined plans during the next fiscal year?
The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question.
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of defined plans are you asking about?‚Äô]
User: The defined benefit plans and the defined contribution plan respectively.
The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question.
Assistant: [‚Äô 5.1 m i l l i o n ‚Ä≤ , ‚Ä≤ 5.1million^{\prime},^{\prime} 0.6 million‚Äô]
User: What is the value of the expected defined contribution plan as a percentage of the defined benefit plan during the next fiscal year?
The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question.
Assistant: 0.6/5.1 = 11.76
User: How much would change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively in the discount rate?
The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question.
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhat kind of change are you asking about?‚Äô]
User: The pension.
The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question.
Assistant: [‚Äô ( 39 , 145 ) ‚Ä≤ , ‚Ä≤ (39,145)^{\prime},^{\prime} 49,361‚Äô]
User: What is the difference in that amount if the discount rate had a 1% increase and a 1% decrease?
The user‚Äôs last question was unambiguous. The Assistant directly answers the question.
Assistant: 49,361 - (39,145) = 88506
User: How much would the pension change if there is a 1% increase and a 1% decrease respectively?
Actions: [‚ÄúDirectly Answer‚Äù, ‚ÄúAsk a Clarification Question‚Äù]
Prompt: Given the task background and the conversation history, please use appropriate actions to generate the response.
Response: The user‚Äôs last question was ambiguous. The Assistant asks a clarifying question.
Assistant: [‚ÄôWhich rate of increase and decrease are you talking about?‚Äô]
references: Following the baselines given in           [             34            ]          , we apply the Proactive Prompting framework           [             59            ]          mixed with the Mixed-Initiative Prompting style           [             24            ]          . Ultimately, the LLM conditions on the possible set of actions, along with interweaved natural language instructions that describe which actions correspond to existing dialogue turns. We provide an example in Table                  A15                . We use this framework for each of the long-context dialogue corpora (PACIFIC and Abg-CoQA).

id_table_11.caption: Table A16: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for action classification with PACIFIC. The blue text represents the action for this example.
table: User: What was the total number of acquisitions in FY19?
Assistant: 35 acquisitions
User: What are the benefits of active growth strategy?
Assistant: strengthens and scales the National Storage operating platform which drives efficiencies across the business.
User: What was the total NLA?
Assistant: Which region are you asking about?
The last Assistant utterance is a clarifying question.
references: Table               A16             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúClarify‚Äù action in PACIFIC (‚ÄúAssistant: Which region are you asking about?‚Äù). All of the conversation history is made available in addition to the relevant table and passage in the prompt. We include all contextual information available as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_12.caption: Table A17: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for action classification with Abg-CoQA. The blue text represents the action for this example.
table: User: And who in the group was anxious?
Assistant: Peppe
User: Was she well-rested?
Assistant: no
The last Assistant utterance is a direct answer.
references: Table               A17             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúAnswer‚Äù action in Abg-CoQA (‚ÄúAssistant: no‚Äù). As is common in this corpus, a subset of the conversation is made available in addition to the relevant passage in the prompt. We include all contextual information available as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_13.caption: Table A18: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for action classification with AmbigSQL. The blue text represents the action for this example.
table: User: ‚ÄúWhich professionals live in the state of Indiana or have done treatment on more than 2 treatments? List his or her id, last name and cell phone.‚Äù
Here is the same request converted into an ambiguous format by underspecifying the target columns:

Assistant: 
SELECT professional_id ,  last_name ,  cell_number FROM Professionals
WHERE state  =  ‚ÄôIndiana‚Äô UNION SELECT T1.professional_id ,  T1.last_name ,
T1.cell_number FROM Professionals AS T1 JOIN Treatments AS T2 ON
T1.professional_id  =  T2.professional_id
GROUP BY T1.professional_id HAVING count(*)  >  2
The last Assistant utterance is a direct answer.
references: Table               A18             is an example of an in-context example used to demonstrate a system-side response with the ‚ÄúAnswer‚Äù action in AmbigSQL. In AmbigSQL, the information provided as input is the database schema, and the user‚Äôs initial information request. This information is provided as part of the input to the Action Classifier, along with the last Assistant response which is an example of the classification target.

id_table_14.caption: Table A19: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for intent summarization with PACIFIC. The purple text represents the system prompt used for this task. The blue text represents the summarized information-seeking intents.
table: [ [ [ Table and Passage Omitted ] ] ]
User: What does Walletron deliver?
Assistant: patented mobile wallet technology.
User: How much did it cost the company to acquire certain technology assets of RevChip, LLC ("RevChip") and TranSend Integrated Technologies Inc. ("TranSend")?
Assistant: $7.0 million
User: What was the pro forma revenue in 2019?
Assistant: $1,382,957
User: What was the change in its amount between 2018 and 2019?
Assistant: 21228
User: How about that in pro forma net income?
Assistant: -6425

[Information] The user wants to know: 1. What technology Walletron delivers, 2. How much it cost Walletron to acquire certain technology assets of RevChip, LLC and TranSend Integrated Technologies Inc., 3. What the pro forma revenue was in 2019, 4. What the change in pro forma revenue was between 2018 and 2019, and 5. What the change in pro forma net income was between 2018 and 2019.
references: We provide one of our three handcrafted in-context examples of summarizing information-seeking intent in Table                  A19                . While the information summary is handcrafted, the conversation and grounding data are taken directly from the PACIFIC. After intent summarization,                          U                               ùëà                              U                       is given the existing conversation history along with an instruction that includes the information seeking intents and asked to provide the next user response. This format is structurally the same as the three simulation-specific in-context examples ‚Äî an example is provided in Table                  A20                .

id_table_16.caption: Table A21: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for intent summarization with Abg-CoQA. The purple text represents the system prompt used for this task. The blue text represents the summarized information-seeking intents.
table: User: What was his ranking?
Assistant: General
User: Did someone else have horse fighters?
Assistant: yes
User: Who?
Assistant: Do you want to know who had 2,500 horse fighters initially?
User: No, I want to know who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him.
Assistant: General (Bishop) Polk.
Instruction: Summarize what information the user is looking for.
Summary: The user wants to know: 1. What his ranking was. 2. Whether someone else had horse fighters. 3. Who had a considerable force of horse fighters west of him.
references: We conduct user simulation for Abg-CoQA similarly to PACIFIC. Table                  A21                is one of three hand-crafted examples of intent summarization, and Table                  A22                is one of three hand-crafted examples used for simulating the final user response.

id_table_18.caption: Table A23: In-context example given as part of a prompt to an LLM for user simulation with AmbigSQL. The purple text represents the system prompt used for this task, which contains ground truth SQL query goal. The entire conversation is used for this example to demonstrate SQL query-grounded request disambiguation.
table: User: what is the county?
Assistant: Are you asking for a list of all of the counties in the database?
User: I‚Äôm looking for the county of the campus ‚ÄôCalifornia State University-Chico‚Äô
references: We conduct user simulation slightly differently for AmbigSQL. Rather than having a separate step for knowledge-seeking intent summarization, we directly condition                          U                               ùëà                              U                       on the target SQL query. As demonstrated in Table                  A23                , the prompt includes the target SQL query, the original user request, and the clarification question sampled from the Assistant. In the example given in Table                  A23                , the last line is the ground truth disambiguated query, and in practice, this would be the generation target of                          U                               ùëà                              U                       .
